body:
LGTM. Thanks @gweidner!

When there is more time, we should consider changing src/main/standalone/* to src/main/resources/bin/*, or move it to src/main/resources/standalone/*. We can do string substitution variables with maven filtering to avoid hardcoding version numbers, since we can pull the version number from the pom.
Thank you @deroneriksson for reviewing!  That's a good idea regarding resource filtering.  I'll merge this PR but keep the JIRA open for that.
cc @bertholdreinwald
Cool! Thanks @gweidner

If I specify EPOCH=5, why wouldn't output something like below?

Thank you @prithvirajsen! I'll merge.
Does this second cluster use 10Gb or 1Gb Ethernet?

10 Gb Ethernet:


BTW I wonder if at some point in the future (not on this PR) if we should move some of the version info to _config.yml to possibly simplify its maintenance.
@deroneriksson - yeah, although we end up changing the artifacts themselves sometimes and the rest of the guide might become obsolete, as it did between 0.11 and 0.12.
@dusenberrymw - thanks for the suggestions, updated.
@niketanpansare - could you please review this?
LGTM. Thanks @nakul02

Thanks! 
I'll merge.
cc @mboehm7
LGTM - thanks for the fix @deroneriksson

The code is extensively and very well documented!
Thank you!!!

Thank you @deroneriksson for the updates.
LGTM

Note that it can be difficult to track down whether dependencies such as these are required or not. If these dependencies are indeed needed, most likely NoClassDefFoundErrors will occur under certain situations.
Thank you for reviewing @gweidner!

The meanings of all the weird looking symbols is specified [here](https://github.com/nakul02/incubator-systemml/blob/c0a6e1fb39781bd11230efeb13218166b4f877fb/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/runtime/instructions/gpu/GPUInstruction.java#L38)
it's certainly useful for local debugging but I'd recommend not to push this to master because these stats are supposed to be a clean summary.
I was thinking or providing an option to stats to print "advanced stats", thoughts?

This program passes and gives no error, even though x is assigned nothing:

```
hello=function(){
    print('no return value')
}
x = hello()
```

Could you please check for this condition, i.e. check for the number of arguments in the function definition and match them to where they're being called?
LGTM :+1:
@nakul02 Thank you for helping getting jcuda deployed to maven central! This will be of great assistance to many people out there.

1) In general, I'm open to discuss "multiple levels" for the stats tool but that would require a holistic (i.e., system-wide) design. In any case, I really would like to retain concise summary statistics because a dump of every measurement quickly gets overwhelming, rendering it counter-productive. How about you create a separate class GPUStatistics similar to CacheStatistics for now and use it just for local debugging. Once, we settle on the right abstraction for the user-facing stats output we could simply embed this output. Furthermore, please double check the existing GPU summary statistics - the time/count outputs are supposed to be aligned with the remaining output.

2) Please, note that your current approach of measuring the overhead of statistics collection returns misleading numbers. The two hash table inserts are by far cheaper than getting the time with System.nanoTime(). Of course if depends on the hardware platform, but it can be even micro seconds. Your best estimate of getting the measurement overhead is to run your script twice - with and without stats - and compare the total execution times.

Thanks for the comments @mboehm7.

**_W.R.T 1._**
In general, I think we can both agree that more granular performance counters is a good thing to track down performance problems.

For the current statistics that are printed out, most of it can only be understood by someone familiar with the opcodes used for our instructions and what cache acquire and release mean. Same for most other things reported by statistics. 
This leads to me believe that the statistics aren't meant for a so-called **"end-user"**.

Keeping this in mind, I feel that with this PR, I need to care about the format of statistics only for developers of SystemML. In which case, I should ask the developers of SystemML what format they would like to see for these additional timers. Can you suggest how I should print these additional timers?

CacheStatistics provides specific counters and timers. The code I added to Statistics.java is really minimal. It adds [two](https://github.com/nakul02/incubator-systemml/blob/1b13587a5e5ca4e8f3bbe9670f8f9b3dda00b336/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/utils/Statistics.java#L109-L110) HashMaps and a little bit of code to "[maintain](https://github.com/nakul02/incubator-systemml/blob/1b13587a5e5ca4e8f3bbe9670f8f9b3dda00b336/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/utils/Statistics.java#L553-L597)" them. Also, it makes logical sense to have them in close proximity, code-wise to the [heavy-hitters maps](https://github.com/nakul02/incubator-systemml/blob/1b13587a5e5ca4e8f3bbe9670f8f9b3dda00b336/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/utils/Statistics.java#L107-L108).

Also, could you explain, what you mean when you say "local debugging"? Do you mean, only for the purposes of my current development?


**W.R.T. 2**
"The two hash table inserts are by far cheaper than getting the time with System.nanoTime()." - This runs counter-intuitive to common sense. Could you please provide a reference?

I would not recommend to have non-SystemML related code in Uber jar file. We do have AntLR and wink files in Uber jar, but I am not sure if thats right approach. Unless you convince other way, I would prefer to have jcuda files outside Uber jar.

ad 1) yes, I mean for your current and future development. In fact, there are many users, not just developers, who use this stats tool. So, if we expose statistics through -stats, we have to hold us to a much higher standard than for dev profiling only.
 
ad 2) https://blogs.oracle.com/dholmes/entry/inside_the_hotspot_vm_clocks

@asurve- I suggested adding the jcuda jars to the Uber jar because those jars may not be available in the environment they are run in (Spark) 
The obvious disadvantages are related to release process (Per platform, testing on those platforms, licenses).

**WRT 1)**
Ok, I was thinking of doing this:
- Introduce a GPUStatistics class 
    - move all GPU related statistics there
- Introduce a "-devstats" option and print these advanced statistics only when that is enabled.
    - we could follow this with a key value pair, for instance, "GPU=true", "DNN=true" and so on, if you think that is a good idea, otherwise just print all the advanced stats.

**WRT 2)**
This is surprising, but I read this article: https://shipilev.net/blog/2014/nanotrusting-nanotime/ and he provides performance considerations when using `System.nanoTime()`. Basically, each call can take between `15-30ns` on Linux platforms, and upto `15μs` on a particularly bad case on Windows Server. The `get` on a HashMap [takes](https://dzone.com/articles/how-tinylog-12-will-simplify-your-logging) about `8-10ns` for the size of maps we are working with.
You are right, so then the overhead of statistics collection does return misleading numbers, I shall remove them.

If the `scope` is set to `provided`, it becomes the user's responsibility to download the jcuda jars (there are 16 jars). This makes using a deployment a pain for the user.

On the other hand, (as @niketanpansare and I spoke offline about), the jar becomes bigger and for a feature that is not used every single time, maybe making the jar bigger is not a good idea.

@lresende, @deroneriksson, @bertholdreinwald - do you have any comments/thoughts?
If not, I'll do what @niketanpansare suggested.
Thank you for reviewing @nakul02. I'll look into it.

Assuming jcuda is compatible with Apache License, I see two possible solutions :
- in the binary distro, have something like lib-cuda and have the necessary libs for platforms there
- the other approach, might be just help the users with a simple script that might download the necessary dependencies and put on the right place for the user.

I would prefer not to have this in the "fat-jar"  particularly because of size and platform dependency. But then we might need to add things to classpath in order to run systemml with GPU support.

ad 1) What we usually do is to integrate such integration with certain log levels, usually DEBUG or TRACE depending on the granularity of outputs. This allows people to easily control the information of specific packages from outside of SytemML in a consistent manner. Furthermore, some components have local debug flags; if enabled they set their own output to DEBUG level. For example, please have a look at org.apache.sysml.hops.rewrite.ProgramRewriter.

Unfortunately, these detailed statistics do not semantically fall into the same category as either the `DEBUG` or `TRACE` log levels. Given that trace and debug are going to spit out a massive amount of output, I would like to treat these statistics (and others like it) separately.
These are the log4j logging levels, `ALL < TRACE < DEBUG < INFO < WARN < ERROR < FATAL < OFF`. Unfortunately, there are no other levels for me to fit the advanced statistics into.

In ProgramRewriter, it turns out that the so-called "local debug flag" is a [compile time constant](https://github.com/nakul02/incubator-systemml/blob/082a743dbb366b807067b5bdf1579ecdd3ced3ab/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/hops/rewrite/ProgramRewriter.java#L57). This also seems to be the case for [LibMatrixDNN](https://github.com/nakul02/incubator-systemml/blob/9c31c2ca7624c61357894ec463223c507165d1d8/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/runtime/matrix/data/LibMatrixDNN.java#L53).

Is adding a `-devstats` a bad idea?

yes, these LDEBUG flags are compile-time to allow for quick testing in your local dev environment. However, the log levels can also be easily configured from outside by modifying the log4j.properties file in your classpath. Note that this configuration allows a fine granularity (e.g., different log levels for different packages, so you would simply set DEBUG for the gpu.context package).

I personally don't think it's a good idea to expose this dump of statistics as shown above through a command line option. Instead I would recommend to think about concise summary statistics (to be integrated in -stats) and keep the remaining detailed profiling internal.  However, I'll not stand in your way if you guys want to go ahead with this.

@nakul02  I think adding `devstats` is useful for performance debugging. The key question is how to expose it to the user. I would be in favor of treating devstats as additional statistics printed after statistics, rather than modifying the existing statistics output. Regarding how to enable it, my preference is in the following order:
1. Turned on by a boolean flag in GPUStatistics. Drawback: Requires source code change while performance debugging. 
2. Turned on by -stats and if LOG level is debug. We then can print additional devstats after Statistics.display() with LOG.debug. Drawback: Other debug outputs. Advantage: No additional flag.
3. `-devstats` or via Configuration property.

If you choose option 1, I am OK with the current output as it is not exposed to the regular user. Also, I would like to put 'Configuration property' option after option 1 as it is how we enable WIP features.

@niketanpansare - I am very much in favor of option (3b) , I.e. devstats, followed by option (3a) a system property. I will restructure the code to minimize calls to System.nanoTime(), if the -davstats option is not passed in. But, "hiding" a feature behind a compile time flag is a bad idea, in my opinion. In a couple of months, it will be forgotten and the code for that feature will be left  behind and will not be maintained. The next person trying to read and modify this code will be left confused. If however, this is exposed from the top level down, a decision to yank out this feature can be made in the future (assuming it's not needed) and related code can be cleaned up in one fell swoop, otherwise it will be forgotten. 
Case in point - in LibMatrixDNN, there is a compile time flag - https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/runtime/matrix/data/LibMatrixDNN.java#L53. No one besides the author know of this flag. If the author doesn't work on this anymore, it will be forgotten.

@nakul02 As I said earlier, I like the idea of having `devstats` for performance debugging. My worry is that what this PR attempts to introduce is just `gpu-devstats` (or at best `gpu+dnn-devstats`). If you (or other developers) are interested in generalizing this concept to other components, I am all up for a single `devstats` flag. Since there are no "free lunches", introducing an additional command-line flag (especially if intended only for development for only one component) becomes one more thing an end user has to be educated about ... also, adding a command-line flag has to be accompanied with supporting that feature via other APIs (such as MLContext) as well. If not used by anyone, it eventually becomes one more thing that is forgotten :)

Configuration property has less impact in that regards, as the assumption is that most end-users will use default configuration and only the expert users will attempt to modify the configuration. 

At high-level, we need to ask ourselves two questions:
1. Is the additional info we are providing summarized in statistics (in case of LibDNN it is) ?
2. Will anyone except the engine developer care about the additional info ?

If the answer is yes and no respectively, it is best to fall back to a boolean flag option. If unsure about question 2, the answer almost always is no :)

@niketanpansare - I am very much in favor of either a `-devstats` or `-gpudevstats` and/or a configuration property. In "generalizing this concept to other components", we can either wait until we have everything properly instrumented and then enable `-devstats` or add in the instrumentation incrementally, one component at a time. That is really up to the stakeholders of the project. I for one am very much for the incremental way. If its the everything-instrumented way is preferred, we can move it to a system config property only for now.

I'll have to disagree with your high-level questions and their answers, specifically - "Will anyone except the engine developer care about the additional info".We have a `-debug` [option](https://github.com/nakul02/incubator-systemml/blob/bbefe96b263f697eb3f4e0297379840930356c0d/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/api/DMLScript.java#L293-L293). This is a flag clearly intended for the developers, much more so than a `-devstats` option. Yet it is user-facing. When you say that an end-user needs to be educated about it, what we do is print it out with the help message in usage. If i've haven't misunderstood you, that is all the education we'd need to do. 
Other counter-examples of something only the engine developer would care about is the different kinds of `-explain` (`hops`, `runtime`, `recompile_hops` & `recompile_runtime`). In my opinion, if a end-user is smart enough to understand these various kinds of "explain" dumps, an extra set of numbers printed by `-devstats` or its ilk should be a no-brainer. :)

In any case, I also understand that the `-explain` and `-debug` might be legacy options that have never been revisited under the set of high level questions that you pose and might just be technical debt that we need to clear up.
All I wanted to point out was that there is precedent, and adding a `-devstats` option is nothing extremely out of the ordinary.

@nakul02 I think you misunderstood what `-debug` flag refers to. It enables a GNU-style debugger that DML writer can use for stepping through their DML script (though I have not played with it for about a year :( ).

I'll have to try it out sometime then 😊
My goto way has been remote java debugging through an IDE. A bit old school. 😀
@asurve, @lresende - excluded jcuda from jar and uber jar. The user will be responsible for providing them.
Thanks @nakul02 LGTM

Thanks @asurve.

Docs will be available in https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/docs/devdocs/gpu-backend.md.

thanks for pushing this forward @deroneriksson. Before we discuss the details of the PR, you might want to consider an alternative via a simple rewrite. You could introduce a new rewrite (subclass of HopRewriteRule) and simply inject an as.scalar cast (for 1x1 matrices) or toString (for nxm matrices) whenever you encounter an u(print) with a matrix input. This would be very clean as the entire logic would reside in this rewrite without the need to touch the runtime.
just to add to my previous comment: to enable something like "@@@" + A + "%%%", we would also need to consider b(+) with matrix and scalar-string inputs.

@mboehm7 Thank you for the great feedback. I suspected that injecting as.scalar or toString in the proper locations would be a cleaner solution, but I wasn't sure about the right mechanism to do so, so I implemented the messier solution in this PR. I'll take a look at creating a rewrite by subclassing HopRewriteRule, since a simpler solutions sounds like a great idea.

Added warning messages if a function call does not return a value but is assigned to a variable or variables. I think a warning at this stage is better than an error since before this PR, a LHS value was a requirement when calling a function even if it did not return a value.

Would it be better to just have our [`_py2java ` function](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/python/systemml/mlcontext.py#L121) convert Pandas DataFrames to PySpark DataFrames using Spark's existing logic (i.e. `spark.createDataFrame(my_pandas_df)`), and then pass those into the engine?  That way, we wouldn't have to worry about memory limits, and we could reduce all this redundant logic and simply reuse our internal DataFrame conversion code.  We could do the same for 2D NumPy arrays.

I have not benchmarked the `numpy -> pandas_df -> spark df (which internally will have parallelize) ( in our systemml algo ---> reblock/collect -> convert to mb if matrix fit in cp` as opposed to `numpy -> mb` or `numpy -> blocked numpy -> blocked mb -> mb`. But, I would suspect the performance of latter would be much better. You can think former as passing `csv` data (with additional parallelize/collect calls) and latter as passing `blocked binary data`.

Could you please delete the L2SVM files? The dmlt and Rt extensions are generally used to indicate temporary files - for algorithm testcases, we do not generate them, so this must be a relict from a long time ago. 

That reminds me, down the road, we should remove the entire "old codepath" from our testsuite. There are still various tests that use something like $$op1$$ + $$op2$$, replace these with input arguments, write the temporary dmlt script, and finally execute the script. This stems from a time when we did not have any input arguments (>5 years). Maybe we find a good way to automatically replace these tests.

To try above code, please use following command:
```bash
git clone https://github.com/niketanpansare/incubator-systemml.git
cd incubator-systemml/
git checkout caffe_new_cleanup
mvn -Djcuda.scope=compile clean package 
cd src/main/python/
cp -R ../../../scripts/staging/SystemML-NN/nn .
~/spark-2.1.0-bin-hadoop2.7/bin/pyspark --driver-class-path ../../../target/SystemML.jar --jars ../../../target/SystemML.jar --driver-memory 40g --conf spark.driver.maxResultSize=0
```

Further testing with different Spark and SystemML patch levels revealed that changes to spark yarn client were also required to prevent `java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: com.sun.jersey.api.client.config.ClientConfig`.  Without spark code patch, the job failed early during JavaSparkContext initialization which is consistent with Matthias' findings:

`Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: com/sun/jersey/api/client/config/ClientConfig
        at org.apache.hadoop.yarn.client.api.TimelineClient.createTimelineClient(TimelineClient.java:55)
        at org.apache.hadoop.yarn.client.api.impl.YarnClientImpl.createTimelineClient(YarnClientImpl.java:181)
        at org.apache.hadoop.yarn.client.api.impl.YarnClientImpl.serviceInit(YarnClientImpl.java:168)
        at org.apache.hadoop.service.AbstractService.init(AbstractService.java:163)
        at org.apache.spark.deploy.yarn.Client.submitApplication(Client.scala:151)
        at org.apache.spark.scheduler.cluster.YarnClientSchedulerBackend.start(YarnClientSchedulerBackend.scala:56)
        at org.apache.spark.scheduler.TaskSchedulerImpl.start(TaskSchedulerImpl.scala:156)
        at org.apache.spark.SparkContext.<init>(SparkContext.scala:509)
        at org.apache.spark.api.java.JavaSparkContext.<init>(JavaSparkContext.scala:58)
        at org.apache.sysml.runtime.controlprogram.context.SparkExecutionContext.initSparkContext(SparkExecutionContext.java:214)
        at org.apache.sysml.runtime.controlprogram.context.SparkExecutionContext.getSparkContextStatic(SparkExecutionContext.java:137)
        at org.apache.sysml.runtime.controlprogram.context.SparkExecutionContext$SparkClusterConfig.analyzeSparkParallelismConfiguation(SparkExecutionContext.java:1575)
        at org.apache.sysml.runtime.controlprogram.context.SparkExecutionContext$SparkClusterConfig.analyzeSparkConfiguation(SparkExecutionContext.java:1558)
        at org.apache.sysml.runtime.controlprogram.context.SparkExecutionContext$SparkClusterConfig.<init>(SparkExecutionContext.java:1484)
        at org.apache.sysml.runtime.controlprogram.context.SparkExecutionContext.getSparkClusterConfig(SparkExecutionContext.java:1368)
        at org.apache.sysml.runtime.controlprogram.context.SparkExecutionContext.getBroadcastMemoryBudget(SparkExecutionContext.java:1378)

Unless there are any strong objections, I plan to close this PR **without** merging after 1 day.

Can demonstrate with:
```
import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext._
import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext.ScriptFactory._
val ml = new MLContext(sc)
val dataGen = dmlFromFile("scripts/datagen/genRandData4ALS.dml")
dataGen.in("$rows", 1000).in("$cols", 1000).in("$rank", 100).in("$nnz", 10000).out("X", "W", "H")
val x = ml.execute(dataGen).getMatrix("X")
val als = dmlFromFile("scripts/algorithms/ALS-CG.dml")
als.in("X", x).in("$rank", 100).out("U", "V")
val alsResults = ml.execute(als)
```

Can demonstrate with:
```
import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext._
import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext.ScriptFactory._
val ml = new MLContext(sc)
val dataGen = dmlFromFile("scripts/datagen/genRandData4ALS.dml")
dataGen.in("$rows", 1000).in("$cols", 1000).in("$rank", 100).in("$nnz", 10000).out("X", "W", "H")
val v = ml.execute(dataGen).getMatrix("X")
val als = dmlFromFile("scripts/algorithms/ALS-DS.dml")
als.in("V", v).in("$rank", 100).out("L", "Rt")
val alsResults = ml.execute(als)
```
